column1: 9~9~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services~True~http://www.census.gov/retail/~"The U.S. Census Bureau conducts the Advance Monthly Retail Trade and Food Services Survey to provide an early estimate of monthly sales by kind of business for retail and food service firms located in the United States. Each month
column2: questionnaires are mailed to a probability sample of approximately 4
column3: 700 employer firms selected from the larger Monthly Retail Trade Survey. Advance sales estimates are computed using a link relative estimator. For each detailed industry
column4: we compute a ratio of current-to previous month weighted sales using data from units for which we have obtained usable responses for both the current and previous month. For each detailed industry
column5: the advance total sales estimates for the current month is computed by multiplying this ratio by the preliminary sales estimate for the previous month (derived from the larger MRTS) at the appropriate industry level. Total estimates for broader industries are computed as the sum of the detailed industry estimates. The link relative estimate is used because imputation is not performed for most nonrespondents in MARTS. For a limited number of nonresponding companies that have influential effects on the estimates
column6: sales may be estimated based on historical performance of that company. The monthly estimates are benchmarked to the annual survey estimates from the Annual Retail Trade Survey once available. The estimates are adjusted for seasonal variation and holiday and trading day differences. Additional information on MARTS and MRTS can be found on the Census Bureau website at: www.census.gov/retail.

column1: Description of the survey as provided by the Census
column2: https://census.gov/retail/marts/www/marts_current.pdf"

column1: 52~52~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Z.1 Financial Accounts of the United States~True~http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/z1/~"The Financial Accounts (formerly known as the Flow of Funds accounts)  are a set of financial accounts used to track the sources and uses of funds by sector. They are a component of a system of macroeconomic accounts including the National Income and Product accounts (NIPA) and balance of payments accounts
column2: all of which serve as a comprehensive set of information on the economy’s performance.(1) Some important inferences that can be drawn from the Financial accounts are the financial strength of a given sector
column3: new economic trends
column4: changes in the composition of wealth
column5: and development of new financial instruments over time.(1)

column1: Sectors are compiled into three categories: households
column2: nonfinancial businesses
column3: and banks. The sources of funds for a sector are its internal funds (savings from income after consumption) and external funds (loans from banks and other financial intermediaries). (1) Funds for a given sector are used for its investments in physical and financial assets. Dividing sources and uses of funds into two categories helps the staff of the Federal Reserve System pay particular attention to external sources of funds and financial uses of funds.(2) One example is whether households are borrowing more from banks—or in other words
column4: whether household debt is rising. Another example might be whether banks are using more of their funds to provide loans to consumers. Transactions within a sector are not shown in the accounts; however
column5: transactions between sectors are.(2) Monitoring the external flows of funds provides insights into a sector’s health and the performance of the economy as a whole.

column1: Data for the Financial accounts are compiled from a large number of reports and publications
column2: including regulatory reports such as those submitted by banks
column3: tax filings
column4: and surveys conducted by the Federal Reserve System.(2) The Financial accounts are published quarterly as a set of tables in the Federal Reserve’s Z.1 statistical release.

column2: Albert M. “The U.S. Flow of Funds Accounts and Their Uses.” Federal Reserve Bulletin
column3: July 2001; http://www.federalreserve.gov/pubs/bulletin/2001/0701lead.pdf.

column1: (2)	Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. “Guide to the Flow of Funds Accounts.” 2000
column2: http://www.federalreserve.gov/apps/fof/."

column2: together with the international community
column3: with the aim of supporting macroprudential analysis and assessing strengths and vulnerabilities of financial systems.

column2: hosted by the Statistics Department of the IMF
column3: disseminates data and metadata on selected FSIs provided by participating countries. For a description of the various FSIs

column1: Reporting countries compile FSI data presented on this website by using different methodologies

Users are advised to consult the accompanying metadata (http://data.imf.org/?sk=9F855EAE-C765-405E-9C9A-A9DC2C1FEE47) to conduct more meaningful cross-country comparisons or to assess the evolution of a given FSI for any of the countries."

column1: 242~242~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Recession Indicators Series~False~http://www.oecd.org/std/leading-indicators/oecdcompositeleadingindicatorsreferenceturningpointsandcomponentseries.htm~"These time series are an interpretation of US Business Cycle Expansions and Contractions data provided by The National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) at http://www.nber.org/cycles/cyclesmain.html and Organisation of Economic Development (OECD) Composite Leading Indicators: Reference Turning Points and Component Series data provided by the OECD at http://www.oecd.org/std/leading-indicators/oecdcompositeleadingindicatorsreferenceturningpointsandcomponentseries.htm. Our time series are composed of dummy variables that represent periods of expansion and recession. The NBER identifies months and quarters
column2: while the OECD identifies months
column3: of turning points without designating a date within the period that turning points occurred. The dummy variable adopts an arbitrary convention that the turning point occurred at a specific date within the period. The arbitrary convention does not reflect any judgment on this issue by the NBER's Business Cycle Dating Committee or the OECD. A value of 1 is a recessionary period
column4: while a value of 0 is an expansionary period.

column1: The recession shading data that we provide initially comes from the source as a list of dates that are either an economic peak or trough. We interpret dates into recession shading data using one of three arbitrary methods. All of our recession shading data is available using all three interpretations. The period between a peak and trough is always shaded as a recession. The peak and trough are collectively extrema. Depending on the application
column2: the extrema
column3: both individually and collectively
column4: may be included in the recession period in whole or in part. In situations where a portion of a period is included in the recession
column5: the whole period is deemed to be included in the recession period.

column2: known as the midpoint method
column3: is to show a recession from the midpoint of the peak through the midpoint of the trough for monthly and quarterly data. For daily data
column4: the recession begins on the 15th of the month of the peak and ends on the 15th of the month of the trough. Daily data is a disaggregation of monthly data. For monthly and quarterly data
column5: the entire peak and trough periods are included in the recession shading. This method shows the maximum number of periods as a recession for monthly and quarterly data. The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis uses this method in its own publications.

column2: known as the trough method
column3: is to show a recession from the period following the peak through the trough (i.e. the peak is not included in the recession shading
column4: but the trough is). For daily data
column5: the recession begins on the first day of the first month following the peak and ends on the last day of the month of the trough. Daily data is a disaggregation of monthly data. The trough method is used when displaying data on FRED graphs.

column2: known as the peak method
column3: is to show a recession from the period of the peak to the trough (i.e. the peak is included in the recession shading
column4: but the trough is not). For daily data
column5: the recession begins on the first day of the month of the peak and ends on the last day of the month preceding the trough. Daily data is a disaggregation of monthly data."

column1: 322~322~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Business Leaders Survey~True~http://www.newyorkfed.org/survey/business_leaders/bls_overview.html~"The Business Leaders Survey is a monthly survey conducted by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York that asks companies across its District – which includes New York State
column2: Northern New Jersey
column3: and Fairfield County
column4: Connecticut – about recent and expected trends in key business indicators. This survey is designed to parallel the Empire State Manufacturing Survey

column1: The survey is sent on the first business day of each month to the same pool of about 150 business executives
column2: usually the president or CEO
column3: in the region's service sector. In a typical month
column4: about 100 responses are received by around the tenth of the month when the survey closes.

column1: Respondents come from a wide range of industries outside of the manufacturing sector
column2: with the mix of respondents closely resembling the industry structure of the region.
general business activity
column3: is a distinct question posed on the survey (as opposed to a composite of responses to other questions). Currently
column4: no indexes are seasonally adjusted since none of the series exhibits stable seasonal patterns from a statistical perspective."

column2: as opposed to ""point-in-time"" estimates such as those from past decennial censuses. ACS 5-year estimate includes data collected over a 60-month period. The date of the data is the end of the 5-year period. For example
column3: a value dated 2014 represents data from 2010 to 2014. However
column4: they  do  not  describe  any  specific day
column5: month
column6: or year within that time period.

column1: Multiyear  estimates  require  some  considerations  that  single-year  estimates  do  not.  For  example
column2: multiyear  estimates released in consecutive years consist mostly of overlapping years and shared data. The 2010–2014 ACS 5-year estimates share sample data from 2011 through 2014 with the 2011–2015 ACS 5-year estimates. Because of this overlap
column3: users should use extreme caution in making comparisons with consecutive years of multiyear estimates.

column1: Please see ""Section 3: Understanding and Using ACS Single-Year and Multiyear Estimates"" on publication page 13 (file page 19) of the 2018 ACS General Handbook for a more thorough clarification. https://www.census.gov/content/dam/Census/library/publications/2018/acs/acs_general_handbook_2018.pdf"

column1: 337~337~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Federal Reserve Board of Governors Labor Market Conditions Index~False~http://www.federalreserve.gov/econresdata/notes/feds-notes/2014/updating-the-labor-market-conditions-index-20141001.html~"As of August 3
column3: updates of the labor market conditions index (LMCI) have been discontinued; the July 7
column4: 2017 vintage is the final estimate from this model. We decided to stop updating the LMCI because we believe it no longer provides a good summary of changes in U.S. labor market conditions. Specifically
column5: model estimates turned out to be more sensitive to the detrending procedure than we had expected
column6: the measurement of some indicators in recent years has changed in ways that significantly degraded their signal content
column7: and including average hourly earnings as an indicator did not provide a meaningful link between labor market conditions and wage growth.

column1: The LMCI is derived from a dynamic factor model that extracts the primary common variation from 19 labor market indicators."

column1: 346~346~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Small Area Income and Poverty Estimates~True~https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/saipe.html~Small Area Income and Poverty Estimates (SAIPE) are produced for school districts
column2: counties
column3: and states. The main objective of this program is to provide updated estimates of income and poverty statistics for the administration of federal programs and the allocation of federal funds to local jurisdictions. These estimates combine data from administrative records
column4: postcensal population estimates
column5: and the decennial census with direct estimates from the American Community Survey to provide consistent and reliable single-year estimates. These model-based single-year estimates are more reflective of current conditions than multi-year survey estimates.

column1: 352~352~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Nonmanufacturing Business Outlook Survey~True~https://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/regional-economy/nonmanufacturing-business-outlook-survey~The Nonmanufacturing Business Outlook Survey is a monthly survey of nonmanufacturers in the Third Federal Reserve District. column1: 354~354~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~An Arbitrage-Free Three-Factor Term Structure Model and the Recent Behavior of Long-Term Yields and Distant-Horizon Forward Rates~False~https://www.federalreserve.gov/data/three-factor-nominal-term-structure-model.htm~This research reviews a simple three-factor arbitrage-free term structure model estimated by Federal Reserve Board staff and reports results obtained from fitting this model to U.S. Treasury yields since 1990. The model ascribes a large portion of the decline in long-term yields and distant-horizon forward rates since the middle of 2004 to a fall in term premiums. A variant of the model that incorporates inflation data indicates that about two-thirds of the decline in nominal term premiums owes to a fall in real term premiums
column2: but estimated compensation for inflation risk has diminished as well.

Data for the REO for Sub-Saharan Africa is prepared in conjunction with the semi-annual World Economic Outlook exercises
column2: spring and fall. Data are consistent with the projections underlying the WEO. REO aggregate data may differ from WEO aggregates due to differences in group membership. Composite data for country groups are weighted averages of data for individual countries. Arithmetic weighted averages are used for all concepts except for inflation and broad money
column3: for which geometric averages are used. PPP GDP weights from the WEO database are used for the aggregation of real GDP growth
column4: real non-oil GDP growth
column5: real per capita GDP growth
column6: investment
column9: claims on the nonfinancial private sector
column10: and real and nominal effective exchange rates. Aggregates for other concepts are weighted by GDP in U.S. dollars at market exchange rates.

column1: 370~370~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Financial Access Survey~False~http://data.imf.org/?sk=E5DCAB7E-A5CA-4892-A6EA-598B5463A34C~The Financial Access Survey is the sole source of global supply-side data on financial inclusion

column1: 371~371~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Hornstein-Kudlyak-Lange Non-Employment Index~True~https://www.richmondfed.org/research/national_economy/non_employment_index~The Hornstein-Kudlyak-Lange Non-Employment Index (NEI) is an alternative to the standard unemployment rate that includes all non-employed individuals and accounts for persistent differences in their labor market attachment. It provides a more comprehensive reading of labor market health and is based on research first published by Richmond Fed economists Andreas Hornstein and Marianna Kudlyak
column2: and McGill University economist Fabian Lange.

373~373~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~GDP-Based Recession Indicator Index~True~http://econbrowser.com/recession-index~This index measures the probability that the U.S. economy was in a recession during the indicated quarter. 374~374~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Texas Manufacturing Outlook Survey~True~https://www.dallasfed.org/research/surveys/tmos.aspx~The Texas Manufacturing Outlook Survey (TMOS) is a monthly survey of area manufacturers. Firm executives report on how business conditions have changed for a number of indicators
column2: such as production
column3: new orders
column4: employment
column5: prices and company outlook. Respondents are also asked to report on how they perceive broader economic conditions to have changed (general business activity). For all questions
column6: participants are asked whether the indicator has increased
column7: decreased or remained unchanged. Answers cover changes over the previous month and expectations for activity six months into the future. Participants are given the opportunity to submit comments on current issues that may be affecting their business.

column1: 376~376~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Texas Service Sector Outlook Survey~True~http://dallasfed.org/microsites/research/surveys/tssos/index.cfm~"The Texas Service Sector Outlook Survey (TSSOS) is a monthly survey of area service sector businesses. Firm executives report on how business conditions have changed for a number of indicators such as revenue
column2: employment
column3: prices and company outlook. Respondents are also asked to report on how they perceive broader economic conditions to have changed (general business activity). For all questions
column4: participants are asked whether the indicator has increased
column5: decreased or remained unchanged. Answers cover changes over the previous month and expectations for activity six months into the future. Participants are given the opportunity to submit comments on current issues that may be affecting their business.

column1: About 230 service-providing firms regularly participate in TSSOS
column2: which began collecting data in January 2007. Respondents are broadly representative of service-producing industries in the private sector. TSSOS includes a breakout for respondents in the retail and wholesale sectors
column3: called the Texas Retail Outlook Survey (TROS). TSSOS questionnaires are electronically transmitted to respondents in the middle of each month
column4: and answers are collected over seven business days. TROS respondents receive a slightly different questionnaire
column5: but the survey period and processing is the same.

column1: The service sector makes up the bulk of the Texas economy
column2: accounting for 59 percent of private-sector activity and employing close to 7 million workers. Retailers and wholesalers make up 12 percent of Texas output and account for 1.6 million jobs. Despite the service sector's prominence
column3: there are few timely measures of changes in service sector activity at the state level. TSSOS fills this regional data gap. TSSOS and its retail component
column4: TROS
column5: are highly correlated with monthly changes in regional economic indicators such as private service sector employment
column6: retail employment and retail sales (see related article below)."

column1: 382~382~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Real Trade-Weighted Value of the Dollar by U.S. State~True~https://www.dallasfed.org/research/econdata/rtwvd.aspx~These indexes calculate the inflation-adjusted value of the U.S. dollar against the currencies of countries to which the state exports. The real exchange rates are aggregated across countries for each state using the annual average export share to the country. For the most recent year where export share data is not available
column2: the prior year' number is used instead. The indexes should allow analysts to more precisely identify the exchange rate movements that most affect demand for a state's exports. For more information visit http://www.dallasfed.org/research/econdata/rtwvd.cfm.

column1: 383~383~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Market Value of U.S. Government Debt~True~http://www.dallasfed.org/research/econdata/govdebt.cfm~For many uses
column2: market value more accurately represents the debt burden faced by the U.S. government than the par value. The par value of government debt
column3: which is reported by the U.S. Treasury Department
column4: reflects interest rates at the time the debt was issued while the market value is adjusted to reflect market interest rates as of the observed period. Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas researchers calculate the market value of U.S. government debt series.

column1: A housing unit is owner-occupied if the owner or co-owner lives in the unit
column2: even if it is mortgaged or not fully paid for. A housing unit is classified as occupied if (i) it is the current place of residence of the person or group of persons living in it at the time of interview or (ii) the occupants are only temporarily absent from the residence for two months or less (e.g.
column3: on vacation or a business trip). If all those staying in the unit at the time of the interview plan to stay there for two months or less
column4: the unit is considered to be temporarily occupied and classified as "vacant."

tract in the county to have the same percentage of that group as the whole county. Originally developed by Jahn
column2: Schmid and Schrag [1947].

column1: More information on measures of segregation can be found at https://dash.harvard.edu/handle/1/2958220
Multiyear estimates from the American Community Survey (ACS) are "period" estimates derived from a data sample collected over a period of time
column2: as opposed to "point-in-time" estimates such as those from past decennial censuses. ACS 5-year estimate includes data collected over a 60-month period. The date of the data is the end of the 5-year period. For example
column3: a value dated 2014 represents data from 2010 to 2014. However
column4: they  do  not  describe  any  specific day
column5: month
column6: or year within that time period.

column1: Multiyear  estimates  require  some  considerations  that  single-year  estimates  do  not.  For  example
column2: multiyear  estimates released in consecutive years consist mostly of overlapping years and shared data. The 2010–2014 ACS 5-year estimates share sample data from 2011 through 2014 with the 2011–2015 ACS 5-year estimates. Because of this overlap
column3: users should use extreme caution in making comparisons with consecutive years of multiyear estimates.

column1: Please see "Section 3: Understanding and Using ACS Single-Year and Multiyear Estimates" on publication page 13 (file page 19) of the 2018 ACS General Handbook for a more thorough clarification. https://www.census.gov/content/dam/Census/library/publications/2018/acs/acs_general_handbook_2018.pdf"

column1: 433~433~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Age-Adjusted Premature Death Rate~True~https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/deaths.htm~"Age-adjusted death rates are weighted averages of the age-specific death rates
column2: where the weights represent a fixed population by age. They are used to compare relative mortality risk among groups and over time. An age-adjusted rate represents the rate that would have existed had the age-specific rates of the particular year prevailed in a population whose age distribution was the same as that of the fixed population. Age-adjusted rates should be viewed as relative indexes rather than as direct or actual measures of mortality risk.

column1: 439~439~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Mean Household Wages Adjusted by Cost of Living~False~https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/~Mean household wages in real U.S. Dollars from the American Community Survey adjusted for cost of living using regional price parities from the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis' Real Personal Income for States and Metropolitan Areas.

443~443~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Business Formation Statistics~True~https://www.census.gov/econ/bfs/index.html~"The Business Formation Statistics (BFS) are a product of the U.S. Census Bureau developed in research collaboration with economists affiliated with Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System
column2: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta
column3: University of Maryland
column4: and University of Notre Dame.

column1: The Business Formation Statistics (BFS) provide timely and high frequency data on business applications and employer business formations.  The BFS measure business initiation activity (Business Application Series) as indicated by applications for an Employer Identification Number (EIN) on the IRS Form SS-4. The BFS also provide information on actual and projected employer business formations (Business Formation Series) that originate from these applications
column2: based on the record of first payroll tax liability for an EIN. In addition
column3: the BFS contain measures of delay in business starts as indicated by the average duration between the application for an EIN and the transition to an employer business.

column1: The BFS currently cover the period starting from the third quarter of 2004 (2004q3) onwards at a quarterly frequency. The data are available nationally and by individual states."

column2: by NAICS-Based Product~True~https://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/statistics/state/index.html~

column1: 453~453~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Distributional Financial Accounts~False~https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/efa/efa-distributional-financial-accounts.htm~The Distributional Financial Accounts (DFAs) provide a quarterly measure of the distribution of U.S. household wealth since 1989
column2: based on a comprehensive integration of disaggregated household-level wealth data with official aggregate wealth measures. The data set contains the level and share of each balance sheet item on the Financial Accounts' household wealth table (Table B.101.h)
column3: for each of four percentile groups of wealth: the top 1 percent
column4: the next 9 percent (i.e.
column5: 90th to 99th percentile)
column6: the next 40 percent (50th to 90th percentile)
column7: and the bottom half (below the 50th percentile). The quarterly frequency makes the data useful for studying the business cycle dynamics of wealth concentration--which are typically difficult to observe in lower-frequency data because peaks and troughs often fall between times of measurement. These data will be updated about 10 or 11 weeks after the end of each quarter
column8: making them a timely measure of the distribution of wealth.

column1: 455~455~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Quarterly Summary of State & Local Tax Revenue~True~https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/qtax.html~"The Quarterly Summary of State and Local Government Tax Revenue provides quarterly estimates of state and local government tax revenue at a national level
column2: as well as detailed tax revenue data for individual states. This quarterly survey has been conducted continuously since 1962. The information contained in this survey is the most current information available on a nationwide basis for government tax collections.

column1: For more information about the survey
column2: visit here: https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/qtax/about.html

column1: A Special Note Concerning Revised Data:
Revisions reflect tax collection amounts obtained from three general sources. State and local government respondents have submitted revisions to amounts as originally reported. In other cases
column2: governments have reported data
column3: which we used to replace data that were previously imputed or estimated. Finally
column4: some of the revisions were compiled from government sources
column5: both published and unpublished. For more information
column6: see the survey's methodology here: https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/qtax/technical-documentation/methodology.html"

column1: 456~456~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Sahm Rule Recession Indicator~False~http://www.hamiltonproject.org/assets/files/Sahm_web_20190506.pdf~The Sahm Rule identifies signals related to the start of a recession when the three-month moving average of the national unemployment rate (U3) rises by 0.50 percentage points or more relative to its low during the previous 12 months.

458~458~2020-01-25~2020-01-25~Cotton Production in New England~False~https://www.nber.org/chapters/c1569.pdf~"Data were gathered by the authors from various textile collections deposited at various museums and libraries on the East Coast
column2: and collected from the original business records of textile mills in New England wherever possible. Preference was given to records that were complete and continuous for long periods
column3: and reasonably intelligible.

column1: Reporting techniques differed greatly from mill to mill. To make the data comparable
column2: each mill's output was allocated uniformly over the months covered by the accounting period. The monthly figures were then summed to calendar years. The total cotton production for the region is estimated by adding the production of each individual mill with data available for the given period.

column1: More details about the data are available in the book chapter ""The New England Textile Industry
column2: 1825-60: Trends and Fluctuations"" (https://www.nber.org/chapters/c1569.pdf)."
